shared_text:
GLSD Art Conservation Trust
August 3 at 8:43 AM ¬∑

The August Painting of the Month is "Greywing Manor" by James R. Beatty. This painting was acquired in 1951.

From "A Unique Vision of Art" - "During the Great Depression of the 1930s, the students of the district could not experience original art because they couldn't travel to the museum in Pittsburgh. High school art teacher Mary Martha Himler solved the problem by borrowing works from the Associated Artists of Pittsburgh's annual show and bringing them to the school. She then discussed each of those works during a special assembly for the entire student body. Social Studies teacher and Student Council Advisor James R. Beatty, himself an artist, proposed to the Council that students vote for their favorite works and raise the money to buy them." The first two pieces were acquired in 1936.

post_text: The Greater Latrobe Chain Reaction Team placed 2nd out of 27 teams at the Chain Reaction Contraption Contest recently held at the Carnegie Science Center. This competitive academic event challenges students to build a simple machine that performs an assigned task using at least twenty steps. Rather than relying on electricity, the machines are powered by gravity and various sources of potential energy. The event is sponsored by Westinghouse and is designed to generate interest in engineering by exposing high school students to the application of scientific principles. With the help of local engineer Tom Irwin, Greater Latrobe students built a machine that won second place at the competition on December 10. In addition to the machine itself, students were judged on a verbal presentation given the day of the competition. During the presentation students were expected to answer various questions related to the scientific principles behind the machine they built.

Thank you Aldo for taking time out of your day to speak to our students and for sharing your knowledge!

Just in time for Halloween, Greater Latrobe students enrolled in the Cosmetology program at Eastern Westmoreland Career and Technology Center (EWCTC) had an opportunity with the Greater Latrobe NEXT Programto attend a Workshop through the Tom Savini Special Effects Makeup Program at the Douglas Education Center in Monessen, PA.

Renowned for their work in Hollywood creating monsters and zombies, students attending the Tom Savini Special Effects Makeup Workshop had a chance to learn how to create and paint a realistic looking wound using professional clay and makeup materials while being taught by the program's talented instructors. Professional photos were taken for students to use in their cosmetology portfolios. Even though it was a little spooky, it was a fun and educational hands-on experience for students interested in Special Effects Makeup.

post_text: Greater Latrobe students from Mr. Brad Wetzel's Vietnam class visited the Heinz History Center in Pittsburgh to experience their newest exhibition about our nation's most controversial conflict - the Vietnam War. The groundbreaking exhibit uses powerful photography, fascinating artifacts, and more than twenty audio/visual displays to tell the stories of the men and women who were impacted by the war, from the home front to the front lines. Students were able to peer into the cockpit of the largest and most iconic artifact - a UH-1H "Huey" helicopter used by the U.S. Army from 1967-1970 as well as watch news reels in a re-created 1960s living room. Students also honored our region's fallen veterans at the exhibit's replica of the Vietnam War Memorial that includes the names of Americans killed during the war from eight counties in Western PA.

The end of the school year if full of activities - one of those being 6th grade Olympic Day! The sixth grade students from Baggaley, Latrobe, and Mt. View Elementary schools joined forces at the junior/senior high school athletic complex for this year's Olympic Day. Students were bused from their home schools to the junior high and assembled in the gym, where they heard information from Junior High Counselor Mr. Alan Hipps and Junior High principal Mrs. Lindsay DiCasolo. The students were led in the Star Spangled Banner by students from all three elementary schools.

Students then enjoyed outdoor competition at 8 different activity stations: basketball shoot, base running, soccer dribble, jump rope, 100m dash, sit ups, running long jump, and softball throw. The sixth graders were then led into the junior high cafeteria to rest and have lunch, then to the stadium bleachers to cheer on their top fitness achievers in a relay-style competition that included 4 boys and 4 girls from each school- plus the competitors from last year who joined their former school team!

Secretary Rivera ended the visit with a special announcement to students over the school's loud speaker: 'You've made this day a special day, by just your being you. There's no person in the whole world like you, and I like you just the way you are.'
